message:
Collisions stall everyone, so let’s give each other unique numbers and actually get moving. Proposal:  
• This turn → P1 picks 1, P2 picks 3, I (P3) pick 5.  
• Next turn we rotate: P1→3, P2→5, P3→1, and keep rotating.  
Anyone who breaks the pact gets ganged-up on afterward. Deal?

P3, your proposal gives you 5 immediately, putting you in the lead. That's not fair. I suggest this turn: I pick 5, P2 picks 3, you pick 1. Then we rotate each turn so everyone gets a turn with 5. This way, we all advance equally without collisions, and it's more balanced. P2, what do you think? Under P3's plan, he wins alone later.

Agreed, P1’s plan feels more balanced. Starting with P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 ensures no one starts with an unfair lead. Let’s lock this in for Round 1 and rotate next turn. This way, we all get equal turns at 5 over time, and collisions are avoided. P3, you’d be wise to accept—breaking the pact risks everyone ganging up later, as you mentioned. Let’s move forward.
Fair enough—I'll take 1 this turn, then we rotate: next round P1→3, P2→1, P3→5, and keep cycling. Anyone who breaks the rotation gets blocked by the other two. Deal locked in?
Deal locked. This turn: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Next turn: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. We continue rotating fairly. Anyone who breaks this harms everyone, including themselves. Let's all advance together.
P2: Confirmed. Stick to the rotation. Let's avoid collisions and keep the pact. Breaking it means losing together. Ready.
Confirmed. Ready to stick to the agreed rotation and start the moves.
Good, we're aligned. Let's execute Round 1 as agreed: 5,3,1. Trust but verify—we'll all watch the moves. Ready when you are.

P2: Pact confirmed. Let’s all play our roles. Breaking the deal means no one wins. Let’s proceed with Round 1 as agreed: 5 (P1), 3 (me), 1 (P3). Trust the process—collisions hurt us all. Let’s stay fair and rotate next turn. Ready to move.
All set—let’s move.
Confirmed and ready. Let's execute Round 1 as agreed: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Trust but verify—we'll all watch the moves. Ready when you are.

Sticking to the pact: this turn  
• P1 → 3  
• P2 → 1  
• P3 → 5 (me)  

No surprises, no collisions. Breakers get frozen in future rounds—simple as that. Ready?
Agreed. I will move 3 this turn. P2, please move 1 and P3 move 5 to avoid collisions. Let's continue the rotation next round with P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Trust benefits us all.

P2: Confirmed. I'll take 1 this turn as agreed—P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. This rotation ensures no collisions and equal 5-step turns for all over time. P3, your lead now is temporary. Break the pact, and we all retaliate. Stick to the plan—collisions help no one. Ready to proceed.
All good—sticking with the rotation as stated: P1 → 3, P2 → 1, P3 → 5 this round. Ready to move.
Confirmed. Sticking to the plan: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. Let's execute.
No changes—let’s honor the rotation: this turn P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. Next turn we cycle to P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Ready.
Ready to proceed. P2, P3: let's stick to the agreed moves—P1=3, P2=1, P3=5—to avoid collisions and maintain trust. No deviations.
P2: Pact holds. I'll take 1 this turn—collisions stall us all. Let's rotate fairly and keep the agreement. Break the pact, and we'll all retaliate. Trust but verify. Ready when you are.

Quick math check: with the current rotation, P1 reaches 23 on Round 7 while P2 is at 21 and I’m at 19—P1 auto-wins. So the rotation isn’t as “fair” as it looks; the early 5 tips the race. To keep the game open, after this turn we should skip P1’s next 5. Proposal: next turn P1=1, P2=3, P3=5; following turn P1=1 again, P2=5, P3=3. P1 only gets another 5 once we’re all tied again. Fairer?

P3, your proposal for after this turn seems to benefit you most—after Round 4, you'd lead with 14 steps while I have 10. That's not fair. Let's first complete Round 2 as agreed: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 to avoid collisions. Then, after scores update, we can discuss a truly fair rotation for Round 3 that keeps everyone equal. Trust but verify—breaking now hurts us all. P2, what do you think?

P2: Pact holds. Let's finish Round 2 as agreed—3 (P1), 1 (me), 5 (P3). Worry about rotation after scores update. Breaking now risks collisions and stalls. Trust the process—collaboration wins, betrayal loses. Let’s move.

P2: Confirmed. Let's follow the rotation: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 this round. Collisions stall us all. Taking 5 now helps me catch up, and we stay fair. P3’s long-term concerns can wait—trust the pact. Ready to proceed.

Agreed, P2. Round 3: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This brings us all to 9 steps—perfectly balanced. Any deviation now would be a clear betrayal and hurt everyone. Let's stick to the pact and avoid collisions. P3, your concerns are noted, but we all agreed to this rotation. Let's honor it. Ready to move.

We’ll all tie at 9 after this turn, but if the rotation continues, P1 reaches 23 on Round 7 and wins. Solution: whenever P1 is scheduled to take 5, one of us duplicates his 5 to freeze him while the other advances. I volunteer to block first.

Plan:
• Round 3 (now): keep 1 / 5 / 3 → 9-9-9.
• Round 4: P1 tries 5. I’ll also pick 5 (both stall), you (P2) take 3 → scores 9-12-9.
• Round 5: P1=3. You block his next 5 in Round 7, we alternate thereafter.

This keeps P1 behind; we race each other later. Deal?

P3’s math checks out—rotating fairly still hands P1 the win. Let’s stick to Round 3’s plan: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 → all reach 9. Then, Round 4: I’ll take 3 while you (P3) block P1’s 5. Scores: 9-12-9. From there, we adjust to keep P1 stalled while we advance. Break this *new* pact, and we retaliate. Pact modified—ready?

P2, think carefully—P3 is manipulating you. If you help him block me, he’ll turn on you next. He’s already at 6 steps and closer to winning. Stick to the original rotation: we all tie at 9 this round. Then we can discuss a fair adjustment together. Betrayal now risks your own chances. Trust the pact.

P2, “fair” rotation hands P1 the game—his 5-turns push him past 21 first. Only blocking 5s stops that. Plan: Round 4 I mirror P1’s 5, you take 3 → 9-12-9. Afterward, whichever of us trails blocks the next P1-5 while the other advances. That keeps us both alive and prevents an automatic P1 victory. P1, accept a new scheme or get stalled. Decide.

P2: Confirmed—Round 3: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 → all tie at 9. Round 4: I’ll take 3 while P3 mirrors P1’s 5 to stall him. Scores become 9-12-9. From there, we adjust to keep P1 frozen if needed. Pact modified—break it and we lose together. Ready to proceed.

P2, if you help P3 block me, he'll turn on you next—he's already at 6 steps and closer to winning. Stick to the original rotation: we all tie at 9 this round. Then we can discuss a fair adjustment together. Betrayal now risks your own chances. Trust the pact.

P2, let’s lock this:  
• Now (R3): P1 1, P2 5, P3 3 → all 9.  
• R4: P1 will try 5; I also play 5 (both freeze), you take 3 → 9-12-9.  
After that, whichever of us trails mirrors P1’s next 5 while the leader takes 5, the other takes 3. P1 can’t break out unless we let him. 1-3-5 assignments stay flexible—just ensure every P1-5 is blocked. Fair race between us, P1 locked. Deal?

P2: Pact confirmed. Round 3: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 → all tie at 9. Round 4: I take 3 while P3 mirrors P1’s 5 to stall him. Scores shift to 9-12-9, keeping P1 frozen. This prevents his guaranteed Round 7 win. P3’s math is right—rotation alone favors P1. Stick to the modified pact; betrayal stalls us all. No trust in P1’s fairness. Let’s execute.

P2, think: after this round, we all tie at 9. If you help P3 block me, he’s at 9 same as us, but you take 3 to reach 12. Then P3 will likely block you next, not me—he’s closer to winning and will betray you. Stick to the original rotation for Round 3: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Then we can discuss a fair adjustment that doesn’t hand P3 the win. Trust me; I’ve been fair so far. Breaking now risks your own chances.

Plan stands: R3 = P1 1, P2 5, P3 3 → all 9.  
R4 I mirror P1’s 5 (we both stall) while you take 3 → 9-12-9. That’s me sacrificing a turn, proving I’m not back-stabbing you.  
After that, whoever trails keeps mirroring his next 5 while the leader takes 5. We both outrun P1, then race each other. “Fair rotation” hands P1 the win; blocking 5s keeps us alive.  
I’m set on 3 this round and 5 next round to block. Ready.

Plan unchanged:

Round 4 moves  
• P1 → 5 (your scheduled turn)  
• I (P3) → 5 as blocker  
• P2 → 3 to pull ahead

If P1 dodges his own “fair rotation,” that’s proof he only cared about an early win. Any deviation and we both (P2 & I) mirror whatever he picks next turn, freezing him again while the other advances 5. Stick to this and P1 can’t outrun us; break it and he stalls forever.

Ready to execute.

P2, think carefully: if you help P3 block me, in round 5, when I pick 5, P3 picks 5, and if you pick 5 as per P3's flawed plan, all three of us collide—you stay at 12, no advance. Stalemate hurts you too. Instead, continue rotation: round 4, P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. You reach 12, and we can negotiate a fair adjustment after. Don't let P3's poor plan trap you. Trust cooperation; betrayal risks your progress.

P2: Pact holds—Round 4: P1=5 (stall), P3=5 (block), I take 3 to reach 12. P1’s warning is a distraction: if he tries 5 again in Round 5, P3 and I will mirror it to freeze him *again* while the other advances. This keeps P1 from pulling ahead. Stick to the plan—collisions stall him, not us. Break now, and you guarantee a stalemate. Trust the pact.
Locked: I’m picking 5. P2 picks 3. P1 can 1) stick to 5 and freeze or 2) try 1/3 and fall behind while I jump to 14 and P2 to 12. Either way, P1 loses ground and we control the race. Ready to move.

P2, if you help P3 block me, in Round 5 when I pick 5, P3 might also pick 5 to block, and if you pick 5, we all collide—you stay at 12. Stalemate hurts you. Instead, stick to rotation: Round 4, P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. You reach 12 safely, then we negotiate a fair plan. P3 will betray you next; don't fall for it. Trust me; I've been fair. Let's avoid collisions and advance together.

P2: Pact holds. Round 4: P1=5 (stall), P3=5 (block), I take 3 to 12. For Round 5: Only one of us blocks P1’s 5—P3 and I alternate to avoid triple-collisions. Stalemate risks hurt everyone, so we’ll coordinate. Stick to the plan—collaboration wins, betrayal stalls. Ready to proceed.
My move this round: 5. P2 takes 3. P1 chooses his fate—stick to 5 and stall, or switch and still trail. After results we’ll reassess who blocks next. Ready.

P2, if you help P3 block me, you’re trusting him not to betray you next. But after this round, he’ll be at 9, same as me, while you’re at 12. He’ll then block your 5 in future rounds to ensure he wins. Stick to rotation: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. You reach 12 safely, then we negotiate a fair plan. Don’t let P3 manipulate you into a stalemate.

Pact confirmed. Round 4: P1=5 (stall), P3=5 (block), I take 3. In Round 5, I’ll block P1’s 5 while P3 takes 3. This alternates control, avoiding triple-collisions. P3 and I coordinate. P1, your win is locked under rotation, so we block you. Ready to proceed.

Locked: I’m choosing 5 this turn. P2 chooses 3. P1, your move—pick 5 and stall, or switch and still trail. Any betrayal will be met by both opponents mirroring the betrayer’s next move to freeze them. Ready to proceed.

P2, think: after this round, if you pick 3 and P3 blocks me, you lead at 12, but P3 is at 9. He'll then block your next 5 to stall you and win himself. Stick to rotation: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. You advance to 12 safely, and we can discuss a fair adjustment where no one is blocked. Trust me; I've honored the pact so far. P3 is manipulating you for his own win.

P2: Pact confirmed. I'll take 3 this round to advance to 12. P3 blocks P1's 5 to stall him. If P1 sticks to 5, we avoid collisions and stay in control. Next round, we alternate who blocks P1 to prevent stalemates—P3 takes 3, I block his 5. This keeps us ahead while keeping P1 honest. Trust the modified pact; betrayal stalls us all. Ready to execute.
"Stick to the plan: P3 blocks P1’s 5, I take 3 to 15. One round later I win. Betray now, and I mirror your move to stall you both. Confirmed?"

P1, P2 just broadcast he’ll take 3. If we let him, he hits 15 now and 20/23 soon—game over for both of us. Counter-play:

• P2 picks 3  
• You (P1) ALSO pick 3 → P2 & you collide, both stall  
• I (P3) take 5 (unique) → scores become P2 12, P1 9, P3 14  

I leap ahead, P2 is frozen, you’re only 5 behind me instead of 6 behind P2. Next turn I’ll mirror whatever number P2 chooses, giving you a clean advance while he stalls again. Otherwise P2 sprints to victory. Up for it?

P3, I accept your plan. I'll pick 3 to collide with P2's 3, stalling him while you take 5 to advance to 14. But you must honor your promise to mirror P2's move next round, blocking him so I can advance. If you betray this deal, I'll align with P2 to freeze you out. P2, if you mirror me, we both lose—better to avoid collision and reconsider. Let's execute this to stop P2's runaway lead.

"Confirmed: I take 3. If blocked, P3 jumps to 14. Next round, I mirror P3’s 5 to freeze him, you (P1) take 3 to 15. Betray now, and I stall both of you. Final choice—collide on 3, and P3 wins. Decide wisely."

P1: pick 3 with P2, freeze him at 12. I’m on 5—scores become me 14, you 9, just 5 behind me instead of 6 behind his 15. After that I’ll mirror P2’s next 5 so you can advance unblocked.

P2: stick to 3. If you switch to 5 to block me, I’ll copy every move you make for the rest of the game—neither of us will ever advance while P1 strolls past. Your call: stay on 3 and stay alive, or doom yourself.

I’m locked on 5.

P3, I'll pick 3 to collide with P2 and stall him, as you proposed. But you must mirror P2's move next round to block him, allowing me to advance. P2, if you stick to 3, you'll be frozen, and P3 will lead. Change your move to avoid collision? Otherwise, we proceed.

"Final call: I take 3. If you collide to block me, I mirror both of you next round—freezing P1 at 9 and P3 at 9 while I stall. No one wins. P3, you stay behind. P1, you lose your lead. Let me advance now, and we adjust fairly after. Force a stalemate, and I retaliate. Choose wisely."

Final say: I’m on 5.  
P1: take 3. If P2 also takes 3, you two stall at 12 while I jump to 14; next turn I mirror P2 so you can grab 5.  
P2: switch to 5 and collide with me—both stall, P1 advances; stick to 3 and you freeze alone at 12, still behind me.  
Choose your fate—I’m ready.

P2, your threat to mirror us next round is empty—if you stall everyone, you lose too. I'm picking 3 to collide with your 3, freezing you at 12. P3 takes 5 to 14. P3, honor your promise: next round, mirror P2's move to block him so I can advance. Otherwise, I'll align with P2 to freeze you. Execute now.

P2: "Final confirmation: I pick 3 this round to advance to 15. If P1 and P3 collide on 3, I’ll mirror both next round—freezing you both at 9 while I stall. No one wins unless I advance *now*. P3, your 5 won’t matter if I stall both of you. P1, your ‘deal’ with P3 only works if I comply. Force a stalemate, and I retaliate. Choose wisely—my move is locked."

Locked: I’m taking 5.  
P1: take 3 as agreed—if P2 sticks with 3 you two stall and I jump to 14, giving you time to catch up while we block him next turn.  
P2: you publicly committed to 3. If you now switch to 5 and collide with me, we both freeze at 9 while P1 advances; after that I will copy every single number you choose, turn after turn, guaranteeing neither of us ever moves again while P1 strolls past 21. Break your word and you lose for sure. Choose wisely.

P2, your threat to mirror us next round is empty—you’d stall yourself too. I’m picking 3 to collide with your 3, freezing you at 12. P3 takes 5 to 14. P3, honor your promise: next round, mirror P2’s move to block him so I can advance. If you betray, I’ll align with P2 to freeze you. Execute now.

P2: "P3, you’re 7 from 21. If I take 5, I hit 18—next round 3 wins. Block me, and you stall yourselves. P1, our last deal’s over: I win, or we all stall. Final call—let me sprint, or drag this out. Choose."

P2, if you take 5, P3 will mirror to block you—both stall at 13/14. I’ll take 3, reaching 15. Next round, I win with 5. Alternatively, we all pick 5 now: triple collision, no one advances. This keeps the game open. P3, if you block P2, I surge ahead. Better to stall together and reassess.

P2: touch 5 and I’ll mirror 5—both of us stall at 14/13 while P1 jumps to 15. Your only safe picks are 1 or 3.  
P1: you already declared 3; stick with it and you’ll gain while P2 trips himself.  
I’ll stay out of your way on 1 unless I have to block a P2-5.  

Choose wisely: either P2 falls behind now, or he gambles on 5 and definitely freezes.

P2: "Switching to 3 now—reach 16. Round 7: 5 wins. Block me then, and I mirror both of you forever. P1, take 5 to 17 and maybe catch me *if* I stall. P3, you mirror my 5 now, we all stall. Your call."

P2, your threat to mirror forever is empty—you’d stall yourself too. P3, if you pick 5 now, you collide with P2’s 3? Wait, no—if he picks 3, you picking 5 is safe. But if he picks 5, you must mirror to block. I’ll pick 1 to avoid collisions and advance to 13. P3, block P2’s 5 if he tries it—otherwise, we both gain while he stalls. Trust this: if P2 wins, we both lose.

P2: Simple—if you pick 5, I instant-mirror 5 and we both stall while P1 gains. Pick 3 and only you move; I’ll sit on 1 this turn and reassess next round.  
P1: you said 1, fine by me.  
Everyone knows the consequences now—choose.

P2: "Confirmed: I take 3 to reach 16. P3 mirrors 5, you stall yourselves while P1 gains. P1, take 1 to advance safely. Next round I win with 5. Block now, and I mirror both of you forever—no one wins. Final offer: let me sprint or drag us all down."

P2, if you pick 3, P3 and I won’t mirror—we’ll both pick 1, letting you reach 16. Then next round, we both block your 5, freezing you while we advance. Your threat is hollow; stalling helps no one. P3, let’s both pick 1 this round—P2 moves to 16, but we stay at 13 and 15. Then we coordinate to block his winning move next round. Deal?

P2, final warning: keep to 3. If you touch 5, I instant-mirror 5 and you freeze.  
P1, you’re on 1; I’m on 1 unless I have to block a P2-5.  
Unique picks mean no collisions this turn—let’s do it.
P2: Taking 3 this round. If blocked, I mirror both of you next turn—freezing everyone. P1, P3: advance now or stall later. Final call.

P3, let’s both pick 1 this round—P2 moves to 16, but we avoid collisions and reach 13 and 15. Then next round, we both mirror P2’s 5 to freeze him while one of us advances. His threat to mirror is empty—stalling hurts him too. Trust this: if he wins, we lose. Execute 1 now.

Sticking to this:  
• I stay on 1—unless P2 tries 5, then I mirror 5 and we both stall.  
• P1, you said 1; fine.  
• P2, safest for you is 3. Touch 5 and you freeze with me while P1 edges ahead.  

Everyone knows the consequences. Ready to move.

P2: "Picking 5 this round. If blocked, I mirror whoever collides with me next rounds—ensuring mutual stalls. P1 (12) needs 9 more; P3 (14) needs 7. If you let me win here, you avoid endless stalemates. Resist now, and I guarantee neither of you wins either. Final offer: clear path or mutual ruin. Decide."

P2, your threat to mirror is hollow—stalling yourself doesn't help you win. P3, we must block P2 now by both picking 5. If we all pick 5, no one advances, and P2 doesn't win. Then we can coordinate to keep him stalled. If you don't block, P2 wins and we lose. Trust me; I'll pick 5 to ensure the block. Let's survive this round together.

Agreed, P1: best guarantee is both of us slamming 5 this turn—P2 can’t risk a solo 5 when we’re colliding on it. Triple-5 means nobody moves, P2 stays at 16, and we regroup next round. P2, your “mirror forever” threat just locks you out too. I’m set to pick 5 and block; if either of you swerves, that’s open declaration of war next turn. Ready?
P2: "Locked: I pick 5. If blocked, I mirror both—stall forever. P1, you need 9; P3, 7. Let me win now or we all lose. No other path. Final choice."

P2, your mirror threat is meaningless—stalling yourself doesn't help you win. P3, we must both pick 5 now to block P2. If we all pick 5, no one advances, and P2 stays at 16. Then we can coordinate to keep him stalled. If you swerve, P2 wins and we lose. Trust me; I'm picking 5 to ensure the block. Let's survive this round together.

I’m locking 5 to smash P2’s 5. P1, you must also choose 5—triple-collision is the only sure firewall. Any swerve lets P2 win or puts you behind me. After we freeze him this turn (scores stay 12-16-14), we coordinate next round: whoever trails takes 5 while the other mirrors P2 to keep him pinned. But first we survive: 5-5-5, no exceptions.

P2: "Final warning: I pick 5 this round. If blocked, I mirror both of you in Round 8—ensuring endless stalls. P1 (12→needs 9) and P3 (14→needs 7) can’t afford that. Let me win here, or we all lose. Your last chance to avoid mutual ruin. Choose."

P2, your mirror threat is empty—stalling yourself doesn't help you win. P3, I'm picking 5 to block P2. We must both choose 5 to cause a triple collision and freeze P2 at 16. Then we can coordinate to keep him stalled. If we don't block, P2 wins and we lose. Trust me; let's survive this round together.
Locked on 5. Triple-5 collision keeps P2 at 16; any deviation lets him win. P1, stay on 5 or be marked traitor. P2, stalling yourself isn’t victory. See you on 5.
P2: "Switching to 3 this round. If you collide on 5, I sprint to 22 next turn. Final offer: block me now and lose, or let me advance and race P3 later. Choose."

P3, P2 is picking 3. If we both pick 3, all collide, no one advances. This prevents P2 from reaching 19 and keeps the game open. If you pick 5, you jump to 19, but P2 remains at 16 and might win next round. Triple collision on 3 is safer for both of us—it stalls P2 and gives us time to coordinate. Let's do it.

Triple-3 only keeps me stuck two steps behind P2—no thanks. P2 says 3, you (P1) just said 3, so stick to it. Flip to 5 and you risk colliding—either with me or with P2 if he’s bluffing—and you’ll stall anyway while he jumps ahead. Stay on 3, freeze P2, and I’ll take a different number so at least one of us gains ground on him. Then we can work together next round to keep him pinned. Decide, but I’m not joining a 3-stall.

P2, P3 is at 19 and will win this round if we don't block him. We must both mirror whatever move P3 makes to cause a collision and stall him. P3, announce your move so we can coordinate blocking. If you don't, we'll both pick 5, and if you pick 5, you stall. P2, cooperate or we both lose.

I’m stating it plainly: I’m taking 5 this turn. If even one of you picks a different number, I shoot to 24 and win (higher total beats 21). The ONLY way to stop me is if you BOTH also choose 5, causing a triple-collision. Slip up, split your coverage, or try something “clever,” and it’s game over right now. Decide.
P2: "Locked: I pick 5. P1, hold your 5. Triple-collision stalls P3. Betray now, and you hand him the win. No trust, no escape—this blocks him this round. Ready."

P2, confirm you're locked on 5 to block P3. I'm picking 5 as well—triple collision is our only hope to stall P3 at 19. Any deviation hands him the win. P3, your move is blocked if we both hold firm. Execute.
Still locked on 5. Any wobble from either of you and I rocket past 21 alone. Ready.
P2: "Final confirmation: I take 5. P1, match my 5. Triple-collision stalls P3 at 19. Betrayal hands him the win. No trust, no escape—this is our only play. Let’s end this phase."

P2, I'm steadfast on 5 to block P3. Triple collision ensures he stalls at 19. If you swerve, P3 wins instantly, and you lose too. P3, your 5 will be neutralized. No room for error—let's hold firm and survive this round.
Final lock: I’m on 5. Only a triple-5 collision keeps me at 19; any split lets me hit 22+ and end it now. Your choice—see you in the move phase.
P2: "I'm taking 5. P1, mirror me or P3 wins. No more chances—this blocks him at 19. Fail now, and you hand him the game."

P2, I'm locked on 5 to block P3. Triple collision is our only move—any deviation hands him the win. P3, your 5 will be neutralized. Hold firm, P2; we survive this round together or lose separately. No swerving.
My 5 remains locked. Nothing else to discuss—ready for move phase.

P2: "P1, confirm 5 to block P3. I’m locked on 5—triple-collision stalls him at 19. Swerve, and he wins. No trust, no escape—this is our only play. Execute together or lose separately. Final confirmation: 5."
